name: World History Survey
description: Major global developments commonly used in introductory history learning paths.

eras.description: Independent transitions to farming and settled life in multiple regions.

sources.title: Neolithic Revolution
sources.snippet: Comprehensive overview of the transition from foraging to farming across multiple world regions.

sources.title: GÃ¶bekli Tepe
sources.snippet: Pre-agricultural monumental site challenging assumptions about the Neolithic transition.

sources.title: Guns, Germs, and Steel
sources.author: Jared Diamond
sources.snippet: Influential theory connecting agricultural origins to long-term civilizational trajectories.

eras.description: Urbanization, writing systems, and early state institutions emerge.

sources.title: Cuneiform
sources.snippet: The earliest known writing system, developed in Mesopotamia for record-keeping and literature.

sources.title: Uruk: The First City
sources.snippet: Metropolitan Museum overview of the world's first major urban center.

sources.title: How Writing Came About
sources.author: Denise Schmandt-Besserat
sources.snippet: Traces writing's evolution from counting tokens to cuneiform script.

eras.description: Major philosophical and ethical traditions form across Afro-Eurasia.

sources.title: Axial Age
sources.snippet: Karl Jaspers' concept of simultaneous philosophical breakthroughs across civilizations.

sources.title: Religion in Human Evolution
sources.author: Robert Bellah
sources.snippet: Major sociological analysis of axial-age religious and ethical transformations.

eras.description: Large imperial systems intensify administration, law, and exchange.

sources.title: Roman Empire
sources.snippet: Overview of the largest classical Mediterranean empire and its lasting institutional legacy.

sources.title: Han Dynasty
sources.snippet: The Chinese empire contemporary to Rome, establishing patterns of bureaucratic governance.

sources.title: Fall of The Roman Empire
sources.author: CrashCourse
sources.snippet: Engaging overview of Roman imperial rise, governance, and eventual transformation.

eras.description: Silk Roads and Indian Ocean routes spread goods, ideas, and technologies.

sources.title: Silk Road
sources.snippet: The network of trade routes connecting East Asia, Central Asia, the Middle East, and Europe.

sources.title: The Silk Road: A New History
sources.author: Valerie Hansen
sources.snippet: Archaeological evidence reshaping understanding of Silk Road exchange patterns.

eras.description: Technological shifts reshape warfare, literacy, and maritime expansion.

sources.title: History of Printing in East Asia
sources.snippet: Chinese and Korean innovations in woodblock and movable type printing predating Gutenberg.

sources.title: History of Gunpowder
sources.snippet: From Chinese alchemical experiments to global military transformation.

sources.title: Zheng He
sources.snippet: Ming dynasty treasure voyages demonstrating early 15th-century maritime reach.

eras.description: Systematic experimentation and mathematical modeling transform natural philosophy.

sources.title: Scientific Revolution
sources.snippet: The transformation of European natural philosophy through new methods and institutions.

sources.title: Principia Mathematica (Newton)
sources.snippet: Newton's foundational work establishing classical mechanics and universal gravitation.

sources.title: The Scientific Revolution
sources.author: Steven Shapin
sources.snippet: Concise revisionist history arguing the 'revolution' was more complex than commonly portrayed.

eras.description: Constitutional and anti-colonial revolutions reshape political legitimacy.

sources.title: French Revolution
sources.snippet: The revolution that redefined sovereignty, citizenship, and rights in the modern world.

sources.title: Haitian Revolution
sources.snippet: The only successful large-scale slave revolution, creating the first independent Black republic.

sources.title: The Atlantic Revolutions
sources.author: CrashCourse
sources.snippet: Overview of the interconnected revolutionary wave across the Atlantic world.

eras.description: Mechanization, fossil energy, and factory systems transform production and society.

sources.title: Industrial Revolution
sources.snippet: The transition to machine manufacturing, new energy sources, and factory organization.

sources.title: The British Industrial Revolution in Global Perspective
sources.author: Robert C. Allen
sources.snippet: Economic analysis of why industrialization began in Britain and its global consequences.

sources.title: Coal, Steam, and The Industrial Revolution
sources.author: CrashCourse
sources.snippet: Engaging summary of how coal and steam reshaped the British and global economy.

eras.description: Global conflicts reshape borders, institutions, and technological trajectories.

sources.title: World War I
sources.snippet: The 'Great War' that destroyed empires and set the stage for the 20th century order.

sources.title: World War II
sources.snippet: The deadliest conflict in human history, reshaping geopolitics and technology.

sources.title: The Second World War
sources.author: John Keegan
sources.snippet: Authoritative single-volume military history of the global conflict.

eras.description: Newly independent states and postcolonial orders emerge across the globe.

sources.title: Decolonization
sources.snippet: The global wave of independence movements that dismantled European colonial empires.

sources.title: The Wretched of the Earth
sources.author: Frantz Fanon
sources.snippet: Foundational text on colonial violence, liberation psychology, and revolutionary theory.

eras.description: Networked computing and global information systems reshape economy and culture.

sources.title: History of the Internet
sources.snippet: From ARPANET to the World Wide Web and global digital infrastructure.

sources.title: Information Management: A Proposal
sources.author: Tim Berners-Lee
sources.snippet: The original proposal that led to the creation of the World Wide Web at CERN.

sources.title: The Rise of the Network Society
sources.author: Manuel Castells
sources.snippet: Seminal trilogy analyzing how information technology reshapes social and economic structures.
